aws::graph::propositions: # Weather and Airport Information for El Monte Airport and Pasadena PD-Benedict Heliport Accident
El Monte Airport reported visibility of 10 statute miles at 1647.
El Monte Airport reported calm wind at 1647.
El Monte Airport reported few clouds at 1,800 feet at 1647.
El Monte Airport reported broken clouds at 3,800 feet at 1647.
El Monte Airport reported overcast clouds at 4,500 feet at 1647.
El Monte Airport reported visibility of 10 statute miles at 1547.
El Monte Airport reported wind from 180-degrees at 6 knots at 1547.
El Monte Airport reported few clouds at 4,200 feet at 1547.
El Monte Airport reported scattered clouds at 4,800 feet at 1547.
El Monte Airport reported overcast clouds at 6,000 feet at 1547.
El Monte Airport is located 8 miles southeast of the accident site.
The Pasadena PD-Benedict Heliport was established in 1972.
The Pasadena PD-Benedict Heliport is situated on a mesa that overlooks the 210 freeway in Altadena, California.
The Pasadena PD-Benedict Heliport was not a certificated heliport.
The Pasadena PD-Benedict Heliport was built prior to California Department of Transportation Division of Aeronautics requirements.
The Pasadena PD-Benedict Heliport had received an exempt status.
In January 1973, the Pasadena PD-Benedict Heliport was designated under the classification of "public safety agencies".
The Pasadena PD-Benedict Heliport was exempted from the Department of Aeronautics heliport regulations.
The Officer in Charge of the air unit responded to the letter submitted by the California Department of Transportation.
The city chose not to pursue certification with the California Department of Transportation.
On-scene documentation of the accident was conducted.
The accident had been recorded on video.
The recorded video showed that helicopter N96BM was moved out of the hangar toward Pad 1.
Helicopter N96BM was parked to the west and outside of the painted square that denoted Pad 1.
Helicopter N96BM was placed in-between Pad 1 and Pad 2 facing south.
The distance between the outside of Pad 1 to the outside of Pad 2 was 33 feet.
The distance was measured by a total station provided by the Pasadena Police Department.
After the impact, both helicopters came to rest upright.
After the impact, there was minimal displacement/movement of each helicopter.

text:
# Weather Obtained

Weather obtained at 1647 for El Monte Airport (EMT), El Monte, California, 8 miles southeast of the accident site, indicated visibility as 10 statute miles, calm wind, cloud conditions as few clouds at 1,800 feet, broken at 3,800 feet, and overcast at 4,500 feet. At 1547, EMT reported weather conditions as visibility 10 statute miles, wind from 180-degrees at 6 knots, clouds conditions, few at 4,200 feet, scattered at 4,800 feet, and overcast at 6,000 feet.

## AIRPORT INFORMATION

The Pasadena PDBenedict Heliport was established in 1972; it was situated on a mesa that overlooks the 210 freeway in Altadena, California. The heliport was not a certificated heliport as it was built prior to California Department of Transportation (DOT) Division of Aeronautics requirements; as such, it had received an exempt status.

According to a letter from the California DOT, dated July 13, 1979, in January of 1973, the heliport was designated under the classification of "public safety agencies," and will be exempted from the Department of Aeronautics heliport regulations. It was deemed that the heliport was exempt, and could continue to operate as such.

The OIC (Officer in Charge) of the air unit responded to the letter submitted by the DOT and the city chose not to pursue that.

## WRECKAGE AND IMPACT INFORMATION

On-scene documentation was conducted. The accident had been recorded on video. The recorded video showed that N96BM was moved out of the hangar toward Pad 1. The helicopter was parked to the west and outside of the painted square that denoted Pad 1, which placed N96BM in-between Pad 1 and Pad 2 facing south.

The distance between the outside of Pad 1 to the outside of Pad 2 was 33 feet, as measured by a total station provided by the Pasadena Police Department.

After the impact, both helicopters came to rest upright, with minimal displacement/movement of each helicopter.
